licence_overview:
If you operate a centre which is involved in the artificial reproduction of animals, you must have a licence from the [Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD).](http://www.dardni.gov.uk "Department of Agriculture and Rural Development"){:rel="external"}

##How to apply

Contact DARD for information on how to apply for a licence. Your licence application may be subject to a fee.

##Conditions

In order to issue a licence, DARD must be satisfied that you are a suitable person to hold a licence and that:

* issuing a licence won't encourage the spread of disease
* you have adequate facilities for the collection, storage, distribution or sale of semen

You can't import the semen or ova of any animal into Northern Ireland unless permitted under your licence and unless you are acting in accordance with the conditions of the licence. 

This doesn't apply to:

* bovine semen which is the subject of Council Directive 88/407/EE
* bovine embryos which are the subject of Council Directive 89/556/EEC
* porcine semen which is the subject of Council Directive 90/429/EEC
* equine ova and embryos which are the subject of Commission Decision 95/294/EC
* equine semen which is the subject of Commission Decision 95/307/EC
* ovine and caprine semen, ova and embryos which are the subject of Commission Decision 95/388/EC
* porcine ova and embryos which are the subject of Commission Decision 95/483/EC

You must allow any person with written authorisation from DARD to enter any:

* premises, vehicle, stall or place in order to check whether any activity requiring a licence has been carried out without a licence
* premises or place used in connection with a licence in order to establish whether there has been a breach of the terms of the licence

However, if the premises in question are private dwellings, you are only obliged to allow the authorised person to enter where they are acting under the authority of a warrant, or if you have been given at least 24 hours' notice of the intended entry.

You must allow an authorised person to inspect any premises, place, animals, plant or equipment, and to carry out tests or investigations.

If you are required to do so by an authorised person, you must give any required information, produce any records you are required to keep and allow copies to be taken of such records.

##Fines and penalties

If an authorised person believes that an offence has been committed, they may seize and detain any semen or ova and their containers, and any animal, plant, equipment or documents.

%If you fail to comply with these rules, you may be liable to a fine of up to £5,000, up to three months imprisonment, or both.  In addition, any semen, ova or animal detained may be forfeited.%



*[DARD]: Department of Agriculture and Rural Development
